class_notes:
Architecture is a branch of knowledge that relies on abstract graphic and material conventions to convey its content. The ability to "read" architecture, a language comprised of drawings, models, renderings, photographs, films, buildings, and landscapes, is a skill that must be acquired. This course is organized by the primary forms of architectural representation to cultivate in students new modes of seeing the built environment through mastery of architectural conventions. Lectures focus on design projects that highlight the potential of the representational tool in question, and seminal readings introduce students to varying modes of architectural writing. Course work includes reading responses, discussions, and hands-on drawing and modeling projects. We will study architecture as a process of imagination, design, negotiation, construction, and reception, and will explore critical and social issues of space, representation, and meaning. Class size is limited to allow for group pin-ups and reviews. 
Architectural Studies minor: core requirement
Art History major/minor: makers & materials course
Note to students:  Dr. Merrill, Director of Undergraduate Studies, is temporarily listed as primary instructor, but this class will be taught by Hayri Dortdivanlioglu. Information will be updated when Prof. Dortdivanlioglu has his Emory ID in place.
